title.gco:CharacterString: Australia - Ecological Communities of National Environmental Significance Database (Public Grids)

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Australia - Ecological Communities of National Environmental Significance Database (Public Grids) 2018

abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Database of Ecological Communities of National Environmental Significance stores maps, taxonomic, ecological, and management information about Ecological Communities of National Environmental Significance listed in the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC) Act 1999 as threatened ecological communities. EPBC listed threatened ecological communities data is available in this generalised gridded form for public download.

Spatial data for Threatened Ecological Communities has no legal status and must always defer to the Conservation Advice. It is unsafe to use the spatial data only to decide if an ecological community of national environmental significance occurs at a particular location.

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

explanation.gco:CharacterString: The positional accuracy of spatial data is a statistical estimate of the degree to which planimetric coordinates and elevations of features agree with their real world values. The planimetric accuracy attainable in the vector data will be composed of errors from three sources: 1. The positional accuracy of the source material 2. Errors due to the conversion processes. 3. Errors due to the manipulation processes. This specification cannot prescribe a figure for the planimetric accuracy of the existing source material used for capture of ecological community distributions as it has already been produced. The errors due to the digitising process depend on the accuracy of the digitising table set-up or the scanner resolution, systematic errors in the equipment, errors due to software and errors specific to the operator. An accepted standard for digitising is that the line accuracy should be within half a line width. The data has been generalised to a 100m grid for the the majority of Australia with a 1km grid used for Western Australia at their request.

Tests are undertaken to ensure that there are no errors in attributes: - The spatial resolution of the data is reflected in the Presence Catagories - Presence categories are one of 2-Ecological community likely to occur within area 1-Ecological community may occur within area (general indication only)
Tests undertaken for logical consistency: - Names of export files and data quality table are correct - Table names are valid - Data format, projection and data type are correct

The database is continually being updated as the lists of threatened ecological communities on schedules of the EPBC Act are amended. Public gridded vector product will be updated annually. The data has been generalised to a 100m grid for the the majority of Australia with a 1km grid used for Western Australia at their request.

statement.gco:CharacterString:
The Ecological Communities of National Environmental Significance Database contains general information about the occurrence and distribution of threatened ecological communities listed under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Act 1999 (EPBC ACT). Departmental information on the distribution and occurrence of EPBC listed ecological communities is contained within the Species Profile and Threats database (SPRAT: http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-bin/sprat/public/sprat.pl). Threatened ecological community information can be obtained from linked recovery plans, conservation advices, policy documents and simplified location maps. Lists of threatened ecological communities that occur in a location can be generated through the Protected Matters Search Tool (http://www.environment.gov.au/epbc/protected-matters-search-tool) available on the Department of the Environment and Energy’s webpage. Distribution models of threatened ecological communities have been developed to allow the Department to respond to the frequent requests from natural resource managers seeking spatial information in a suitable format for regional scale planning. The release of the generalised data version of the ECNES (Ecological Communities of National Environmental Significance) database has been developed to allow the public to access distribution information of Australia’s threatened ecological communities. The data have been generalised at 100m, with the exception of those ecological communities occurring within Western Australia which are at 1km. The data have been derived from maps created by spatial ecologists within the Department of the Environment and Energy. These maps have been created using ecological data, research information, observation records, vegetation mapping and modelling software with national-scale environmental data. They are predictive models of the occurrence of a given ecological community and should be considered as indicative rather than a definitive assessment of presence or absence. They represent a starting point for further investigation rather than the outcome of a comprehensive scientific assessment. The generalised distributions provide an indication of the spatial certainty of presence by classifying into one of two presence categories: likely to occur or may occur. The ‘likely to occur’ presence category is an approximate boundary of the current extent of the ecological community. The boundaries have often been delineated using State and Federal vegetation mapping polygons. However, ecological communities are defined by the interactions of species and physical characteristics, and it can be difficult to develop an absolute indication of where a community does or does not occur. The uncertainty in the ‘likely to occur’ boundary reflects the Department’s need to balance accurate and useful information for natural resource managers, and a legally and scientifically defensible method of protecting important ecological communities where they occur. The ‘may occur’ presence category is typically the outer perimeter of where the ecological community could be encountered, although the community may still be found outside the boundary. Generally, the ‘may occur’ category encompasses the range of ecological and biophysical characteristics that have been used to define the community in the listing advice. The ‘may occur’ boundary often reflects other natural boundaries, like vegetation groups and geological features. Spatial data has no legal status and must always defer to the Conservation Advice. It is unsafe to use the spatial data only to decide if an ecological community of national environmental significance occurs at a particular location.
Ecological communities listed since last public grid release (Nov 2017): - Assemblages of species associated with open-coast salt-wedge estuaries of western and central Victoria ecological community (COM_ID 132) - Coastal Swamp Oak (Casuarina glauca) Forest of New South Wales and South East Queensland ecological community (COM_ID 142)

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Referrals Spatial Database (c) Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy (2018).

abstract.gco:CharacterString: The Referrals Spatial Database records locations of referrals submitted to the Department under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC Act) 1999. A proponent (those who are proposing a development) must supply the maximum extent (location) of any proposed activities that need to be assessed under the EPBC Act through an application process. Referral boundaries should not be misinterpreted as development footprints but where referrals have been received by the Department. It should be noted that not all referrals captured within the Referrals Spatial Database, are assessed and approved by the Minister for the Environment, as some are withdrawn before assessment can take place. For more detailed information on a referral a URL is provided to the EPBC Act Public notices pages. Status and detailed planning documentation is available on the EPBC Act Public notices (http://epbcnotices.environment.gov.au/referralslist/). This includes some summary statistics and public notifications. In the first instance where a proponent provides GIS data through a referral application, this is loaded as the polygons for a referral. Where this doesn't exist other means to digitise boundaries are employed to provide a relatively accurate reflection of the maximum extent for which the referral may impact. This sometimes takes the form of heads up digitising planning documents, sourcing from other state databases (such as PSMA Australia) features and coordinates supplied through the application forms.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: The Referrals Spatial Database records locations of referrals submitted to the Department under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC Act) 1999.

credit.gco:CharacterString: Where a derivative is generated or redistributed under Creative Commons licence, the licensor must credit the Department of the Environment and Energy and provide a link to the source (this will usually be to where the data was originally downloaded from).

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: This data has been licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Australia Licence. More information can be found at http://www.ausgoal.gov.au/creative-commons.

Referral spatial boundaries are indicative only and should not be used to define the totality of onground works including being used as a substitute for an onground development footprint. Through the assessment and approval process, boundaries may be updated by a proponent to reflect improved understanding of the extent of a development. Where advised ERIN update the EPBC Act Referrals Spatial Database to reflect these changes however no guarantee is given to this.
(c) Commonwealth of Australia (Department of the Environment and Energy) 2018
CC - Attribution (CC BY)

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

explanation.gco:CharacterString: Accuracy varies depending on the accuracy supplied by the proponent and the method of data entry by ERIN officers.

The Referral loading tool constrains a user to a pick list of referral identifiers that a boundary can be loaded under. This reduces any human error that could occur when loading a referral.
The area in hectares and referral IDs are automatically calculated to reduce errors.
Attributes about a referral, for example name and status information, are imported from the Department's EPBC Chapter 4 database.

The Referral Gateway Section within EACD checks referral locations in referral applications using google maps. The coordinates are also validated by ERIN before loading into the spatial layer.
Where referred boundaries are not a good representation of the referred spatial area, ERIN will refine boundaries using publicly available referral documents or the proponent is engaged to provide improved boundaries.
The data is for those assessments referred that fall under the EPBC Act. It does not include boundaries for State/Territory and local planning instruments.

statement.gco:CharacterString:
Until early 2006 locational data was only stored as a 10 - 25km buffer around a site or pair of coordinates. Since then all sites have been accurately mapped and a program of remapping all buffered sites has been initiated and completed.
Locations are currently entered by staff in the Environmental Resources Information Network (ERIN) Branch of the Department, who are responsible for spatial mapping and data management. Data is checked with referral documents and any data issues such as self intersection, or wrong coordinates of a referral are corrected where possible.
When a new referral is submitted existing departmental systems generate a unique referral ID based on the year and referral number (e.g. 2014/3928). The database only captures this referral ID and a short project title, however we also generate an external link to EPBC referral database where more detailed information on a referral can be found.

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset is indicative of the surface water upstream catchment areas of Australia's internationally significant wetlands (listed under the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands). These data are used as reporting layer in the Protected Matters Search Tool and assists in assessing proposed activities (EPBC referrals) for potential downstream impacts against Ramsar wetlands.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: Indicative of surface water upstream catchment areas of Australia's internationally significant wetlands (Ramsar)

credit.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy, 2018
Australian Hydrological Geospatial Fabric (Geofabric) v2.0 © Commonwealth of Australia (Bureau of Meteorology) 2014

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

explanation.gco:CharacterString: Polygons selected as catchment boundaries in areas of moderate to significant relief may be assumed to be accurate to plus/minus 250m.

Attirbutes are: Refcode = unique Australian Wetlands Database reference code Ram_name = ramsar wetland name Poly_type = Polygon type either Ramsar (site boundary), Buffer (of ramsar site) of Catchment (upstream catchment).
100% accurate.
See ftp://ftp.bom.gov.au/anon/home/geofabric/
Complete

statement.gco:CharacterString:
The Ramsar Upstream Catchment Boundaries Layer is derived using:
1. Each of the Ramsar Wetland site's boundaries 2. A 10km buffer area to each site, clipped to 3km where the buffer area extends seawards from the coast 3. A catchment for each site from an upstream trace process using the Australian Hydrological Geospatial Fabric (Geofabric) features and relationships 4. A multi-ring buffer, intersect and erase process to divide the catchment into distance bands from the Ramsar site
Geofabric data used: SH_Network\AHGFNetworkNode SH_Network\AHGFCatchment - Geofabric Surface Catchments - V2.1.1 SH_Network\AHGFNetworkConnectivityUp
To derive upstream catchments areas, a conservative process was enlisted. The catchment(s) intersecting each Ramsar site was selected as the inputs, and the nodes within those catchment(s) then traced upstream.using the relationships listed in the ConnectivityUp table. The nodes are attributed with the catchment to which they are in, and the sum of all catchments identified become the total catchment area.
A multiring buffer of each site was clipped with the catchment area to create the final product after merging with the site boundary and 10km/3km site buffer.
16/02/2016 Revised Narran Lakes Nature Reserve to include the extended area of the site, and the extended 10km buffer zone. The upstream catchment remained largely unchanged.
15/11/2018 Revised Moreton Bay upstream catchments to include the Brisbane and Logan River catchments as found in: Marston, Frances. & CSIRO. Land and Water. 2000, Sediment sources, transport and deposition in the Moreton Bay Catchment : existing data and previous research / Frances Marston CSIRO Land and Water [Canberra] <http://nla.gov.au/nla.arc-13482>

title.gco:CharacterString: Habitat critical to the survival of marine turtles in Australian waters

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment

abstract.gco:CharacterString:
In Australia, all six species of marine turtles that occur in our waters are protected under the Australian Government's Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) and various State and Northern Territory legislation.
Flatback Turtle (Natator depressus) Green Turtle (Chelonia mydas) Hawksbill Turtle (Eretmochelys imbricata) Leatherback Turtle (Dermochelys coriacea) Loggerhead Turtle (Caretta caretta) Olive Ridley Turtles (Lepidochelys olivacea)
Under section 270(2)(d) of the EPBC Act, 'Habitat critical to the survival of the listed threatened species' must be identified in the Recovery Plan for Marine Turtles. The criteria for describing habitat critical to the survival of a species for marine turtles was determined in accordance with the EPBC Act Significant Impact Guidelines 1.1 - Matters of National Environmental Significance. The guidelines define 'habitat critical to the survival of a species' as areas necessary: • activities such as foraging, breeding or dispersal • for the long-term maintenance of the species (including the maintenance of species essential to the survival of the species) • to maintain genetic diversity and long term evolutionary development • for the reintroduction of populations or recovery of the species.
The mapped areas were identified by consensus of a panel of experts in marine turtle biology.

credit.gco:CharacterString: Habitat critical to the survival of marine turtles in Australian waters. COPYRIGHT Commonwealth of Australia, Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy, 2018

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

explanation.gco:CharacterString: The polygons are not comprehensive nor do they represent absolute limits.The polygons show indicative limits of habitat critical to the survival of marine turtles, in Australian waters, that have been identified to date.
Attribute information has been developed using current scientific knowledge of each species at the time of collection
This dataset represents habitat critical to the survival of marine turtles in Australian waters

Spatial and attribute data associated with the habitat critical polygons were complete at the time of collation. With further research, other habitat critical areas may be identified and/or the areas depicted in the data may be refined.

statement.gco:CharacterString: The 'habitat critical' spatial data was derived following discussions with numerous species experts. While the polygons are not comprehensive nor represent absolute limits, they represent the 'habitat critical' areas that have been identified to date. With further research, other important areas may be identified and/or the area identified in this data may be refined. The data was gathered to support the Recovery plan for marine turtles in Australian waters.

title.gco:CharacterString: Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation for Australia (IBRA), Version 5.1

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation of Australia (IBRA) Version 5.1, Department of the Environment and Heritage, September 2000

abstract.gco:CharacterString: IBRA regions represent a landscape based approach to classifying the land surface of Australia from a range of continental data on environmental attributes. 85 biogeographic regions have been delineated, each reflecting a unifying set of major environmental influences which shape the occurrence of flora and fauna and their interaction with the physical environment. IBRA Version 5.1 is the result of refinement of the IBRA Version 4 boundaries. These refined boundaries were jointly defined by the Commonwealth, State and Territory nature and conservation agencies. Following a Departmentally facilitated workshop on the revision of boundaries on 24 July 2000, spatial data refinements were undertaken by DEWHA in conjunction with relevant State / Territory agencies. Agreement from all contributing parties, to make the final IBRA5_1 dataset publicly available, was gained in November 2000. Nominal attributes for the IBRA are; climate, lithology/geology, landform, vegetation, flora and fauna, and landuse. The use of these attributes varies across the States and details can be found in "Revision of the Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation of Australia (IBRA) and Development of Version 5.1 - Summary Report", DEH, Sept 2000. This dataset is available in ArcInfo export file format, Projection Geographicals, Datum and Spheroid WGS84. It is also available as Arcview shapefiles.

credit.gco:CharacterString: Geoscience Australia, National Mapping Division - Internal State boundaries of Australia.
State/Territory government departments: - delineation of IBRA boundaries
NSW: National Parks & Wildlife Service (NSW NPWS)
VIC: Dept of Natural Resources and Environment (DNRE)
TAS: Dept Primary Industries, Water and Environment (DPIWE)
WA: Dept of Conservation & Land Management (CALM) & Department of Agriculture
SA: Dept of Environment and Heritage (DEH)
NT: Parks & Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory (PWCNT)
QLD: Department of Environment (DoE)
Australian Government Department of the Environment and Heritage, Reserve System Section - edge matching of IBRA boundaries and compilation of national coverage

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: CC - Attribution (CC BY)
This data has been licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence.
© Commonwealth of Australia (Department of the Environment and Heritage) 2000

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

explanation.gco:CharacterString: Less than two kilometers in most areas of Australia. Generally the data is at least accurate to 1:250,000

The IBRA data has five attributes: * Reg_code - The two or three letter abbreviation for the IBRA region * Reg-name - The full name of the IBRA region All region abbreviations and names have been double checked by State/Territory authorities and are correct. * Prior-97 - The priority allocated to the IBRA region in 1997 for the enhancement of the National Reserve System. These priorities are based on IBRA v4 and will be reviewed in 2001, to reflect the boundary changes in IBRA v5. The priorities are allocated to assist in the development of a CAR reserve system (representative, comprehensive and adequate). * State - Standard Geoscience Australia state boundaries have been incorporated in IBRA v5. * Reg_no - the number allocated to each IBRA region; consistency with IBRA4 has been maintained where possible.
All polygons are correctly labelled.
The data are complete and up to date.

statement.gco:CharacterString: The original IBRA data (1995) were compiled from various scales of mapping by the State/Territory nature & conservation agencies onto a 1:3 million scale base map. Since 1995, all States & the Northern Territory have reviewed and enhanced these data to improve the spatial positioning of the boundaries and homogeneity of the regions. In 2000, The Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy collated the proposed changes to the IBRA regions, appended the State/Territory data into a national coverage and held a workshop to discuss anomalies across State/Territory borders. DEWHA then undertook spatial refinements of the boundaries (using landsystems, geology, vegetation and image data), in conjunction with State/Territory agencies to ensure that the edgematching of region boundaries reflected environmental variation. The Geoscience Australia 1:100,000 coverage was used to maintain a standard for the internal borders of the State/Territories of Australia. The coastline boundary is as received from each of the States and the Northern Territory, with the exception of NSW and QLD where the Geoscience Australia coastline has been used. IBRA version 5.1, with 85 Bioregions, was ratified by all the States/Territories in October 2000.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

title.gco:CharacterString: Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation for Australia (IBRA), Version 5.1 - Sub-regions

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Interim Biogeographic Regionalisation for Australia (IBRA), Version 5.1- Sub-regions, Department of the Environment and Heritage, Canberra, 2000

abstract.gco:CharacterString:
IBRA version 5.1 Sub-regions, like their parent regionalisation IBRA version 5.1, represent a landscape based approach to classifying the land surface of Australia from a range of continental data on environmental attributes, at a finer scale. 354 IBRA Sub-regions have been delineated, each reflecting a unifying set of major environmental influences which shape the occurrence of flora and fauna and their interaction with the physical environment. The IBRA Version 5.1 Sub-regions are the result of refinement of the IBRA Version 4 boundaries. These refined boundaries were jointly defined by the Commonwealth, State and Territory nature and conservation agencies. Following a DEH facilitated workshop on the revision of boundaries on 24 July 2000, spatial data refinements were undertaken by DEH in conjunction with relevant State / Territory agencies.
Nominal attributes for the IBRA and IBRA Sub-regions are; climate, lithology/geology, landform, vegetation, flora and fauna, and landuse. The use of these attributes varies across the States.

credit.gco:CharacterString: VIC: Dept of Natural Resources and Environment (DNRE)
TAS: Dept Primary Industries, Water and Environment (DPIWE)
Australian Surveying and Land Information Group (AUSLIG) - Internal State boundaries of Australia.
State/Territory government departments: - delineation of IBRA boundaries
NSW: National Parks & Wildlife Service (NSW NPWS)
WA: Dept of Conservation & Land Management (CALM) & Department of Agriculture
SA: Dept of Environment and Heritage (DEH)
NT: Parks & Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory (PWCNT)
QLD: Department of Environment (DoE)
The Australian Government Department of the Environment and Heritage, Reserve System Section - edge matching of IBRA boundaries and Sub-region boundaries and compilation of national coverage

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: CC - Attribution (CC BY)
This data has been licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence.
© Commonwealth of Australia (Department of the Environment and Heritage) 2000

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

explanation.gco:CharacterString: Less than two kilometers in most areas of Australia. Generally the data is at least accurate to 1:250,000

The IBRA ver5.1 Sub-region data has six attributes: * STATE - Standard AUSLIG State abbreviations * SUB_NAME - the name used in the Landscape Health project. This attribute has not been verified by all States/Territories and is not used as a unique identifier. * SUB_CODE - the first three letters are based on the IBRA reg_code (or State modified IBRA code) plus an integer (identifying that sub-region within the larger IBRA region). Eg. CYP3 - Cape York Penninsula sub-region 3. * SUB_NO - a unique Sub-region number * REG_CODE - the two or three letter abbreviation for the IBRA region * REG_NO - the number allocated to each IBRA region; consistency with IBRA ver4 has been maintained where possible.
All polygons are correctly labelled.
The data are complete for IBRA version 5.1. Further refinement is being carried out by the States and Territories.

statement.gco:CharacterString: The original IBRA data (1995) Version 4, was reviewed by the department in the year 2000 because many of the States/Territories had enhanced and improved the spatial positioning of boundaries and were using IBRA Sub-regionalisations for conservation planning and management pourposes. The National Land and Water Resources Audit (NLWRA) had proposed a project to assess Australia's Landscape Heatlh at an IBRA Sub-region scale. Thus DEWHA collated IBRA regions and Sub-region data from the States/Territories and undertook spatial refinements of the boundaries (using landsystems, geology, vegetation and image data), in conjunction with State/Territory agencies to ensure that the edgematching of region and Sub-region boundaries reflected environmental variation and homogeneity. The AUSLIG 1:100,000 coverage was used to maintain a standard for the internal borders of the State/Territories of Australia. The coastline boundary is as received from each of the States and the Northern Territory, with the exception of NSW where the AUSLIG coastline has been used. Thus, the IBRA Sub-regionalisation was used as the basis for analyses and reporting in the Theme 7 Ecosystem Health - Landscape Health project in 2000/2001. In 2000 another proposal was put forward - to use the IBRA Sub-region data as the base scale for analyses and reporting in the NLWRA Theme 9 Biodiversity - Biodiversity Assessment Project. This was agreed to by all States and Territories. PLEASE NOTE: The States /Territories are continuing to work on their sub-region boundaries and as of August 2001 had not yet reached agreement for this national dataset to be used outside of the two aforementioned NLWRA projects.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

title.gco:CharacterString: National Flying-Fox Monitoring Program (NFFMP) - Camp Register

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment

abstract.gco:CharacterString:
National Flying-Fox Monitoring Program (NFFMP) camp register. The national flying-fox monitoring program commenced in 2013 and is a collaborative project between the Australian, NSW, Queensland, Victorian, South Australian and ACT Governments and CSIRO Land and Water. It involves quarterly counts at all known daytime roost sites of grey-headed and spectacled flying-foxes across both species' national ranges, and at black and little-red flying-fox camps where those camps occur within the range of the previous two species or outside these ranges, where monitoring is possible. The aim of the program is to establish a reliable benchmark for flying-fox populations in 2013 and monitor trends in abundance and distribution in subsequent years. Counts are carried out using a robust scientific methodology developed by the CSIRO Land and Water (this method is described at http://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/pages/391f5fed-e287-4dd3-85ac-640037926ef5/files/310112-monitoring-methodology.pdf, http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/threatened/publications/status-and-trends-australias-epbc-listed-flying-foxes). The first full NFFMP census of grey-headed flying-foxes took place on 14-16 February 2013 and was the most comprehensive survey ever undertaken for this species.
The NFFMP is coordinated by CSIRO Land and Water and Department of Environment in collaboration with the participating state governments.
This dataset contains all the flying-fox census data collected under the NFFMP (up to and including survey results reflected in the data revision date).

credit.gco:CharacterString: The data custodian is the National Flying-fox Monitoring Program partner organisations. These are Commonwealth, State, Territory governments and CSIRO. The NFFMP is a NESP emerging priorities funded project.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Restricted

The long term ambition of the NFFMP is to make the data publicly available. However, at present the camps and counts data are not available for public release via direct data download. Aggregated data are displayed by an external facing WebGIS viewer. Data could be released for research purposes under standard licence by negotiation with NFFMP.
Discuss any use of the data with NFFMP body

statement.gco:CharacterString:
The project methodology, coordination and reporting is by CSIRO Ecosystem Sciences. The quarterly census counts are performed by volunteer counters from state and territory government officers and volunteers and coordinated by CSIRO. The quarterly data and report is compiled by CSIRO and delivered to DoE.

title.gco:CharacterString: National Flying-Fox Monitoring Program (NFFMP) - Flying Fox Census

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment

abstract.gco:CharacterString:
National Flying-Fox Monitoring Program (NFFMP) Flying Fox Census. The national flying-fox monitoring program commenced in 2013 and is a collaborative project between the Australian, NSW, Queensland, Victorian, South Australian and ACT Governments and CSIRO Land and Water. It involves quarterly counts at all known daytime roost sites of grey-headed and spectacled flying-foxes across both species' national ranges, and at black and little-red flying-fox camps where those camps occur within the range of the previous two species or outside these ranges, where monitoring is possible. The aim of the program is to establish a reliable benchmark for flying-fox populations in 2013 and monitor trends in abundance and distribution in subsequent years. Counts are carried out using a robust scientific methodology developed by the CSIRO Land and Water (this method is described at http://www.environment.gov.au/system/files/pages/391f5fed-e287-4dd3-85ac-640037926ef5/files/310112-monitoring-methodology.pdf, http://www.environment.gov.au/biodiversity/threatened/publications/status-and-trends-australias-epbc-listed-flying-foxes). The first full NFFMP census of grey-headed flying-foxes took place on 14-16 February 2013 and was the most comprehensive survey ever undertaken for this species.
The NFFMP is coordinated by CSIRO Land and Water and Department of Environment in collaboration with the participating state governments.
This dataset contains all the flying-fox census data collected under the NFFMP (up to and including survey results reflected in the data revision date).

credit.gco:CharacterString: The data custodian is the National Flying-fox Monitoring Program partner organisations. These are Commonwealth, State, Territory governments and CSIRO. The NFFMP is a NESP emerging priorities funded project.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Restricted

The long term ambition of the NFFMP is to make the data publicly available. However, at present the camps and counts data are not available for public release via direct data download. Aggregated data are displayed by an external facing WebGIS viewer. Data could be released for research purposes under standard licence by negotiation with NFFMP.
Discuss any use of the data with NFFMP body

title.gco:CharacterString: Australia - European Carp (Cyprinus carpio) distribution - (100m Grid)

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Department of the Environment. and Energy (2018). Carp Distribution (100m Grid). Commonwealth of Australia, Canberra.

abstract.gco:CharacterString: In conjunction with the National Carp Control Plan the Department has developed the Carp capture tool. This tool is being used during the consultation phase of the potential release of the Carp herpes virus, to capture the known location of Carp and information about these sites to help policy makers understand the potential impacts of the invasive species. Key stakeholders involved in data collection for Carp include Natural Resource Management groups, local government areas and other targeted stakeholders. Observation point records for Cyprinus carpio were retrieved from the Department's Species Profile and Threats database and the Atlas of Living Australia (June 2018). Geographic range descriptions and habitat information were also sourced from available scientific literature and recent academic research. Jurisdictional information (including location descriptions and geospatial data) was specifically sought from the States and Territories as well as the Murray Darling Basin Authority to confirm the known presence of the species in Australia’s waterways. The habitat layers used to create this distribution comprise the relevant features of the: a) DEM derived AHGF Network Stream data (Australian Hydrological Geospatial Fabric v2.1.1); b) the waterbody features captured in the Geodata Topo250k v4.0 product suite (Geoscience Australia); and, c) the 1-in-100 year flood boundary for the Murray-Darling Basin. These features were all buffered by 250m to create an area (polygon) extent and compensate for any spatial inaccuracies in the source data. The ‘known to occur’distribution comprises the main stream segments located between the furthest upstream and downstream observed or described locations (including a 5 km buffer either side of these outer locations). Any perennial waterbody features in contact with known stream segments or described as containing the species were also captured in the ‘known to occur’presence category. The likely distribution comprises the stream segments (up to 5km) throughout the network that are in contact with the known extent. Any perennial waterbodies occurring within 1 km of known extents were also captured in the ‘likely to occur’presence category. The may distribution comprises all of the remaining major stream segments and waterbodies found within the drainage basins known to contain the species. The 1-in-100 MDB flood extent was also captured in the ‘may occur’ presence category. The dataset is a gridded polygon dataset at a 100m resolution. This is the final version of the dataset with edits made based on additional information from the Carp capture tool and consultations with key stakeholders.

credit.gco:CharacterString: Department of the Envrionment and Energy (Commonwealth), Canberra
Murray Darling Basin Authority (Commonwealth), Canberra
Environment, Planning and Sustainable Development Directorate (ACT Government), Canberra
Department of Environment and Heritage Protection (Queensland Government), Brisbane
NSW Office of Environment and Heritage (New South Wales Government), Sydney
Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (Victorian Government), Melbourne
Department of Primary Industries and Regions SA (South Australian Government, Adelaide
Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development (West Australian Government), Perth
Tasmanian Government, Hobart
Atlas of Living Australia - CSIRO (Commonwealth), Canberra

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

explanation.gco:CharacterString: The maps represent best available information and comprise a range of scales and reliability. Species distributions have been generalised to 0.001° (~100m) grid cells.

Tests are undertaken to ensure that there are no errors for the following attributes: - TAXON identifiers are unique, valid and within the allocated range - Presence categories in the database are one of: - Species or species habitat is likely to occur within area - Breeding recorded within area - Breeding or breeding habitat likely to occur within area - Roosting recorded within area - Foraging recorded within area - Listed Critical Habitat
Where additional areas have been added to a distribution through the use of an automated modelling tool at a higher level of presence than existing mapped areas, they have been altered to the existing minimum value.
Scripts ensure that each map has consistent fields, and standard codes are used throughout.

The database is being updated as the lists of species on schedules of the EPBC Act are amended, and new information on distribution becomes available. Updates are undertaken when new data becomes available and resources permit.
Based on sensitive species policies, the maps of these species are withheld from the public grids version : Kings Lomatia Lomatia tasmanica (Tas). The distributions of migratory species such as shore birds may not reflect the total distribution within Australia but only show breeding sites, sites of significance or known locations. For more information on individual species distributions, please contact the relevant state agency.

statement.gco:CharacterString:
The Spatial information is stored in a geographic information system and links to the Taxon and Species Profile tables through the taxon identifier.
Source data were provided from a range of government, industry and non-government organisations.
Testing is carried out using expert opinion, and/or through reference to published information.
The lineage of each species map is detailed in the stored item.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy
Australian Government Department of the Environment

abstract.gco:CharacterString:
Based on Local Government Areas (CONTEXT_SDE.Local_Government_Areas) and supplemented with State Borders (CONTEXT_SDE.state_borders_100k) joined to LGA kerbside recycling data provided by Planet Ark.
The attributes for collection services indicate the existence of a service in that LGA.
No collection - There is no kerbside collection of this product in this LGA Collected - Kerbside collection is available for the product in this LGA Some collection - There is limited collection of the product in this LGA. The limitation may be based on geography, dwelling type or limitations based on the type of product No data - We have not received data for this LGA No local govt - There is no local government in this area i.e. unincoprorated area

credit.gco:CharacterString: All maps must display (c) Planet Ark, Geoscience Australia and PSMA [year].

PSMA Australia's preferred position is that each map has a copyright notice. However, If the document is "bound" and the pages cannot be removed without damaging the book (ie hard bound or soft bound book) then a single copyright notice within the publication will be acceptable. Otherwise, a copyright notice on each map is required.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Australian Government Department of the Environment and Energy

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Restricted

As per the PSMA LGA data, this data is available only to staff within the Department. The data is not to be made available in digital form to third parties. Permission has been granted from the vendor to use this data in approved on-line applications as a graphical background. Approval should be sort via an email to the gis-helpdesk prior to use in any online applications.

The data may contain inaccurate or incomplete information due to the passage of time, changing circumstances, sources used and the nature of collecting comprehensive geographic data, any of which may lead to incorrect results.
With the exception of some of the plastics, the data provided by Planet Ark has not been validated.

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497

explanation.gco:CharacterString: Positional accuracy is an assessment of the closeness of the location of the spatial objects in relation to their true positions on the earth's surface. The positional accuracy includes: - a horizontal accuracy assessment - a vertical accuracy assessment The horizontal and vertical positional accuracy are the assessed accuracy after all transformations have been carried out. Relative spatial accuracy of Transport and Topography reflects that of the jurisdictional source data. The accuracy is +/- 2 metres in urban areas and +/- 10 metres in rural and remote areas. No "shift" of data as a means of "cartographic enhancement" to facilitate presentation has been employed for any real world feature. The Greenspace and Hydrology Themes are classified as "BB" accuracy. That is, 90% of well-defined features are within 1mm (at plot scale) of their true position, eg 1:500 equates to +/- 0.5metre and 1:25,000 equates to +/- 25 metres. Anecdotal evidence suggests that the spatial accuracy of the major part of the dataset (at all scales) is frequently better than BB.

Attribute accuracy is an assessment of the reliability of values assigned to features in the dataset in relation to their true 'real world' values. Key attributes (name and the unique identifier) have a high degree of accuracy in the order of 99.09%. Other attributes derived from the processing of supplied data may have a lower degree of accuracy but less than previously released data. All attribute accuracies are dependent on the data accuracy supplied to PSMA Australia Limited. For this product, feature and attribute accuracy is a measure of the degree to which the features and attribute values of spatial objects agree with the information on the source material. The allowable error in attribute accuracy was previously up to 5%. A precise attribute accuracy assessment may not always be possible. In these cases an intuitive estimate of the expected attribute accuracy or the likely maximum error based on previous experience is acceptable.

Logical consistency is a measure of the degree to which data complies with the technical specification. The allowable error in logical consistency previously ranged from 3% to 5%. The test procedures are a mixture of software scripts and onscreen, visual checks. The data structure has been tested for conformance with the data model. The following have been tested and confirmed to conform: - File names - Attribute names - Attribute lengths - Attribute types - Attribute domains - Attribute Order in file. - Object type - Compulsory attributes populated
Completeness is an assessment of the extent and range of the dataset with regard to completeness of coverage, completeness of classification and completeness of verification.

statement.gco:CharacterString:
The Kerbside Recycling data was obtained from Planet Ark and, in the case of some of the plastics data, was suplemented with data from the Department of the Environment. The Planet Ark data is collected through their Recycling Near You (RNY) website through input from local councils. Apart from some validation of the plastics collection data, this data has not been validated by the Department.
The RNY data was joined to the Local Government Areas spatial data from PSMA and supplemented with spatial data from Geoscience Australia. There is no common identifier between the RNY and PSMA data so a join field was created and calculated to allow the RNY data to join the LGA abbreviated name in the PSMA data.
Some local governments had multiple entries in the RNY data. These were to indicate different levels of services present in an LGA. Some LGAs provided different services to residential than they did to commercial areas. Some LGAs provided different services to houses than they did to units. Some rural LGAs provided services to towns only or different services to different towns. These multiple record instances needed to be combined into a meaningful single record for each LGA. Services were deemed to cover the whole LGA where they covered all residential areas. This was treated from the point of view of availability, i.e. we asked the question "Is collection *available* for a given product in this LGA?" The following assumptions were made:
All residential = All Houses and Units = All Houses = Some Units = Some Where there were two different services for the same products, one for houses and one for units, this was consolidated into All Houses, townhouses and some units = Some All urban residential properties = Some (as this suggests that there are non-urban residences that are not included) Business or commercial = Some (our primary interest was residential) Only within a prescribed area, zone or specified towns = Some (there are likely to be residences outside the prescribed area) All properties that currently get weekly rubbish collection = Some (suggests some residences don't get weekly rubbish collection) “All residents who pay a waste management charge” or “user pays fee” suggests that collection is available. This the same as All residential = All All houses and some shops = Some (as this seems to exclude residences other than houses) Transfer stations/”Bay Waste Disposal Site” = No collection: this is not a kerbside collection “1200 houses” = Some Residential properties that make a booking = All (collection is available) “All residential properties in township area, private service available in rural areas” = All Residential properties excluding rural = Some Residents receiving a 3 bin collection = Some Designated residential properties = Some “From the contracted collection areas” = Some Resident need to apply for service = All “All properties eligible for a recycling collection service” = Some
In December 2013 the numeric identifiers used previously were replaced with user-friendly textual attributes to allow the attributes to display in a web map with pleasant effect when using the identify function.
The data gives no indication of the frequency of collection. It was noted that the RNY data indicated some collections were weekly or fortnightly but in some cases, the service was provided annually.
